VOL. XXXII, No. 31

11 OPPONENTS FOR
RACQUET WIELDERS
Proctor and Polan Announce
'28 Tennis Schedule—Five
Matches Away
Eleven tennis matches have been
arranged for the 1928 Hopkins tennis team by Manager Bernard Polan
and Captain Kenneth Proctor. Five
of the matches will be played on,
enemy courts, while the remaining
SIX will be.staged at home.
The team will open the season
With a short Southern trip. The
University of Virginia Will be met
April 5, after which the team will
then journey to Lexington, Virginia,
Where the Washington and Lee racqueters will be met the next day.
On April 7, the Jays will complete
their excursion with a match against
Virginia Polytechnic Institute.
•

Cavaliers Return

Franklin and Marshall will be
Played at home on Aprit-20, and
Oil April 26 the Cavaliers from Virginia will visit Homewood to again
match racquets with the Black and
Blue. The Jays will desert Baltimore again on May 1 to play
Georgetown in Washington, but will
return to meet Lafayette on the
fourth.
The annual contest With Maryland
Will be staged at College Park this
Year, and the date will be April 5.
The Terrapins are out to avenge last
Year's defeat, and the Jay racqueters
Will endeavor to help give Hopkins
a clean sweep over their ancient
rivals in all branches of sport during
1927-28.
Last Three Here

• The last three matches of the season will take place at Homewood,
George Washington, New York
University, and Georgetown being
the opponents on May 10, 12 and 15,
respectively.
Proctor is endeavoring to add two
or three more matches to the above
schedule, but no definitE-dates have
been agreed upon as yet.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 10, 1928

ALUMNUS GOSSIP IN "TOWN TOPICS"
Two Hopkins graduates are
the latest victims of Dame Gossip. Town Topics, the scandal sheet of New York, recently published the following statement:
"Chris Johnston has quieted
down quite a bit since his college days, when the Cane Club
was in full swing and he and
Paul Parsons used to go over
to East Baltimore and cut capers. In this way Paul got
in with several of the young
men about town and soon
found himself right in society."
Johnston arid Parsons were
members of the class of 1922,
the former going to the Medical School after his graduation
here. Parsons was a lacrosse
player of note.

Next Jay Will Be
"Wanderlust Number"
According to Donald White, editor-in-chief of the Black and Blue
Jay, the next issue of the Jay will
take its readers to foreign ports
again. "Wanderlust" is the novel
sobriquet given by the Hopkins humorists to this number, which will
appear during the last week in February.
The "Wanderlust Number," stated
White, will be more or less of a
travel number, but treated differently from the so-called "Travel
Numbers" issued in the past. Editorial copy is to be in by the last
of. next week, thus insuring time
enough to get the Jay out by March
1.
The next election of candidates
for the art, editorial and business
staffs will be held immediately after
the Easter recess. Editorial candidates must have their minimum requirement of copy in on time, stated
White, to be eligible for election to
the staff.

DR. C. K. EDMUNDS IS
RECENTLY HONORED
Former Hopkins Provost. Becomes Head of Pomona College; to Try New Experiment
Dr. Charles K. Edmunds, who
was formerly a provost of the Johns
Hopkins University, has been selected as the new head of Pomona
College, ahremont, California.
Besides being connected with
Hopkins, Dr. Edmunds has had interests with Lignon University for
twenty.years. This latter institution was formerly the Canton Christian College, China. First serving
the Chinese college as a member of
its faculty, then as its president, Dr.
Edmunds finally became the director
of the Board of Trustees.

GRADES FOR FIRST
SEMESTER NOW OUT
• For the first time in several
years, official notices of marks
for the first semester are being
placed in the post office boxes
of the students. Official
grades have been sent in, listed,
copied and reports made out.
This has all been done since
examinations.
The girls in the office have
shown surprising efficiency in
getting out the official grades,
and it is hoped that they have
established a precedent that
will be continued. The grades
as statecl in these reports are
official and final, and are not
subject to change.

The distinguished professor will
head one of a group of small colleges; to which equal facilities will
be open. The objcet of this arrangement is to afford the group
the advantages of both the small
college and the large university.
The group is composed of the
Scripps and Pomona colleges, at
present under the name of Claremont Colleges. Another link is to
be added as soon as possible, according to authorities.
Dr. Goodnow's Comment

Dr. Goodnow, president of Hopkins, in speaking of Dr. Edmunds'
new appointment, stated that he was
sorry to see Hopkins lose him. "He
is an excellent man, and I am sure
he will do well in his new work."
added the president.
Under the guidance of the former
provost, the Canton College made
great progress, and became known
as one of the greatest educational
institutions in China. Lignon University is surrounded by 318 acres
of land and consists of 52 permanent
buildings.
One year ago, Dr. Edmunds, with
Dr. William W. Comfort, president
of Haverford College, and Dean
Watts, of Pennsylvania State College, went to China to assist in reorganizing the university "in view
of the nationalistic aspirations of the
Chinese."
The newly appointed head of the
Western college graduated from
Hopkins in 1897, and was the recipient of both the degree of Bachelor of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy from this university. He is a
Fellow of the American Geographical Society and American Physical
Society.

, George Washington's original idea
to found a national university in the
capital of the nation would be affected under the terms of a bill
which has been advocated in the
Senate by Senator Fess, who was
a noted educator before his election
to that body. He proposes to locate an institution of "higher learning," named the National University of the United States, within the
capital, and which would have at its
disposal for scientific research the
$50,000,000 worth of laboratories
and laboratory equipment which are
at present located in Washington.
Under the Fess plan the institution
would be a "super-university." All
students would have to be graduates
of other universities who hold degrees of Master of Arts or Master
of Science; it would be directed by
a board of trustees appointed by
the President with the advice of an
advisory council representing all the
States.

WHY NOT A TRIP FOR THE BARNSTORMERS?
The recent successful Musical Club trip to the Eastern Shore
opens to Hopkins organizations an entirely new field of enterprise, worthy of further exploitation. That section of the State
has too long been looked upon by Baltimoreans as being too inaccessible. As a matter of fact, it is within close proximity of this
city, the trip being a matter of only a few hours.
As the Barnstormers prepare for their new dramatic season
they would do well to consider the possibility of presenting their
play at seireral Eastern Shore towns during the Easter holidays.
It has long seemed the height of folly for the Barnstormers, after
a long period of rehearsing the manuscript and painting the scenery, to give only two public performances. By. the time the actors
have become accustomed to playing their roles before an audience
the play's brief engagement is over.
Members of the club might object to this suggestion on the
grounds of excessive freight charges for transporting stage properties. Such expenditures could easily be eliminated by borrowing
the necessary furniture from merchants in the towns where the
club performs.
People on the Eastern Shore would gladly welcome such an
enterprise. It is a well-known fact that the traveling dramatic
road shows have long ago dropped small towns from their itineraries. Amusement seekers in such drama-starved districts must,
therefore, live on the scanty diet provided by Adolphe Menjou,
Clara Bow and other motion-picture mimes.
The arrival of a good play, capably acted by the Barnstormers,
would create a considerable stir in such towns and should prove
quite profitable at the box office.

DR. GILMAN'S OLD PLEA
There is no more striking note in the publications of the writers
on higher education in this country than that of inadequacy. Despite differences of opinions as pp how the problem is to be met,
the spirit that there is something definitely lacking is, nevertheless,
unanimous.
Typical of articles of this type is one by R. L. Duffus, entitled
"A View of the College of Tomorrow," which appeared in last
Sunday's New York Times. Mr. Duffus believes that one of the
chief weaknesses in American colleges today is the poor quality
of most of the faculties, caused by the insufficiency of endowments. He stresses the point that, except in the extremely rare
case of the man who is willing to join the teaching profession
through pure love of his work, the best scholars and most inspiring
teachers are often lost, because these men are not willing to raise
families on the average salary that most colleges can pay. Nor
does he believe that money alone will be the solution. "Dull instructors beget dull instructors, pedagogically speaking," he says.
There is a great deal to be said in favor of this argument. Inspiring teachers—although not necessarily brilliant scholars—can
often outweigh the evil effects of an inadequate or antiquated system. Although it seems to be becoming more and more patent
every day that the American college must undergo changes in order
to fulfill its mission, it should also be recognized that no matter
how many modifications are made in curricula, these changes
should be accompanied by the attraction to the colleges of men
who cannot only teach youth, but inspire him.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

An alumnus of the University of
Chicago and the president of a large
national concern in that city stated
in a recent address that a college
education is worth $72,000. He
furthermore said that this represents a profit of'1,200 per cent. on
an original investment of $6,000,
which is the average total cost of a
four-year course in college. Deducting the cost of the education
itself, the student adds to his future
income at the rate of $15,000 a year
during the time he is in college. As
classes are held only five days a
week, this means potential earnings
of $70.00 a day to the student for
each day spent in the classroom. We
don't say we believe it all, but doesn't
it work out beautifully on paper?
*

*

*

*

*•

According to information received
from the University of Minnesota,
there is reason to believe that one
student out of every four cheats
in examinations. About 400 students were questioned with the understanding that any information
received would in no way affect their
grades, and that their replies were
to be anonymous. It was then found
that about 18 per cent. of that number were guilty of the offense and
the opinion is that when final investigations are completed the percentage
will have increased to 25.

The following code was recently
published in the undergraduate
newspaper at Syracuse University
as.embodying suggestions from students, faculty and alumni as a basis
for community understanding:
As a Student

I believe that I am entitled
to a full return for time spent
in the classroom and that I

should attempt to secuie it by
a co-operative attitude toward
instructors, a freedom from
antagonism, and evidence of
my desire to understand their
points of view.
I believe that prevalence of
"cribbing" would not only destroy the morals of the college,
but lessen the value of its academic degree. I personally
shall not be guilty of it.
I believe that I have a share
of responsibility for the o'rderly life of the campus, and that
where any form of lawlessness
exists it is my duty to aid in
stamping it out.
I believe that I should not
profit financially by any position of trust or responsibility
connected with student affairs,
unless by an open arrangement fully understood and approved by my fellow students.
I believe that students
should share in the planning
of all legislation which governs student affairs.
As a Teacher

I believe that I should attend
classroom fully prepared, avoiding the stereotyped
lecture and the meaningless
phrase.
I will assume every question,
to be sincerely meant unless I
know to the contrary, and I
will not meet it with sarcasm
or wit at the expense of the
inquirer.
I will avoid pose.
I assert my liberty as a citizen to express freely my opinion on any controversial topic;
but as a representative of the
University I will distinguish
liberty from license, and consider the dignity of the platform upon which I stand.
In publishing my private
opinions I will see to it that
they are represented as my
own and not those of the body
of which I now happen to be
a part.
I believe that the classroom
must not be used for purposes
of propaganda. I consider it
my task to encourage students
to seek the truth, not to force
them to accept my interpretation of it.
I believe that my right to
devote a classroom hour to subject matter remote from the
business of the course is coextendent with the right of the
student to use that hour for
purposes equally remote.
I believe that instructors and
students are assembled here
primarily to carry out an educational program and that any
subordinate interest which
comes into conflict with that

Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
I have always wanted to smoke a
pipe. After several' attempts I gave
my "taste" up, for with each trial I
got a blistered tongue.
One evening, when looking over a
certain outdoor magazine, I read that
a certain fisherman could catch more
fish when using "Edgeworth," so I
decided I would try "his" tobacco—
for I am no poor fisherman!
The next day I tried to secure Edgeworth. The local country storekeeper
did not have it, so I sent by a friend to
the city for my first Edgeworth. Two
things have happened: I still smoke
Edgeworth, and the local storekeeper
always has a supply.
I catch fish and never get "a bite''
from Edgeworth!
Yours for keeps,
H. V. Massey

are three good reasons for examinations. It saves time for professors,
it saves work for the students and if
the proper kind of an examination
is given, the results are not satisfactory either to the teachers or the
students." Dr. Havens described
Professor and students both as getting along best "in a state of happy
ignorance" where no quizzes are
given.
"The review, however, is of incalculable benefit, especially in bringing together scattered points. The
student is not always doing the best
Possible work and the test reveals
that. Of course, the sttbtlest things
cannot be revealed in any art. What
You can test is whether the student
has done his work thoroughly and
intelligently% If he has done that
and the teacher has done his work
Well, the probabilities are that the
student will have the other thing.
In the main, I work on that theory,
but, as in most human affairs, the
Other thing is possible.
Marks. Fallable

"Marks are just like every otherhuman institution—fallable. In life
You will find people rating you much
more arbitrarily than college marks.
They and the test, however, reduce
the probability of error. The race
ls not always to the swifty nor the
battle to the strong. The term
Paper is a very important and valuable thing. It - does not take the
Place of the examination, but neither
does the examination take its place.
The ideal combination consists of
Short tests, two examinations every
Year with long questions, and the
term paper. If I don't give tests
they will not do the work. We must
also remember that in the world we
are always checked up in one way
or another."
Dr. French Sympathetic

hand, expresses himself as, in general, favorable to the proposed plan

Satyr's Lament
That day there 'blew a breeze
Which winnowed winsomely, and brought
A tremor to the lush grass, rippling
Whisp'ringly the tender green,
And shimmering in the trees.
I may be hard to please,
For one who seeks the thing I sought;
God knows—the glistening golden sheen
Of sunlight on the ruffed pool,
And blown leaf-shadows, stippling
Your glowing body, and the breeze—
But stay—
The day was young—and sweet—and wild
And you were such a—fragile—child. .

Pick-Up?
Underfoot the cold rain made sloppy holes in the lingering
custard of snow. The green and 'red lights of traffic posts ran
down the shining black street in alternate 'streams of blood and
absinthe. And toward me came—she. What. I thought, as the
instant recognition of that slightly swaying slimness flashed her
identity through my brain, is she doing on this street, which is so
foreign to her meaning, so distinctly not her street, at this hour of
an adventurous but highly aristocratic evening? 'She saw me;
knew me instantly for the strange, ftinny self-conscious boy who
looked—so often—and smiled—so . . . Because it was an adventurous if aristocratic evening, I slackened my somewhat uncertain
steps. Rebellion burned in her clear eyes, and in her eyes was the
glowing danger of the traffic sign. I looked and smiled.
She placed her feet firmly in the slush. "Why," said she, "are
you always looking at me—and smiling?" Her voice, at last.
Such a voice as it should be—melody under coarse fur—or some
such absurdly impossible thing.
Carefully I paused. "That," I answered, -is too easy. You
are pleasing to look at; T smile when I'm pleased. Where are you
going
"Home, I guess . . . What's it to you. anyway?"
"I'll walk to the bus with you."
"I take the street car."
"Not generally."
"You must be cheap, ain't you?"
"Why?"
The answer was a look. It was no answer. Amusement, a
slight boredom, a dare, a request . . . who can say? A nauseous yellow taxi slithered to a halt in red obedience. A white leer
like something long drowned marred its misted windowpane.
There was a drunken yell.
"Gen'rally," she spat at me quietly, "I take a taxi." She took
the taxi. .
. Perhaps it was a friend of hers. .

Pierced
There is a barb within my heart ;
No trifle hurtled carlessly,
No brutal thrust nor random dart ;
I am not hurt by any part of you ;
knew that words and petty faults could sting-Desired the pain that love would bring ;
It is not that;
Your Being is the barb that wounds my soul ;
You—insenate and unheeding;
I squeeze the gash for what the blood is worth;
You do not see the bleeding.
But in my mind there lingers still a doubt;
Would you regret it if I plucked you out?

"The world is so full of a number of matters,
I'm sure we should all be as crazy as hatters."
How can anyone pretend to thought, when thought is a mere
mad whirl of images and urtmentionable, idiotic dreamings, when
the expression of a thought so frequently precedes realization of
a mental process? To argue or to write is to find out what you
think; in either caw the discovery is astounding-, and one stands
amazed, like
"Stout Cortez . . .
Silent on a peak in Darien."
Bu think what you really think; the disconnected fragments of
totally irrelevant and unrelated reveries that chase each other
through your brain. My mind to me—not a kingdom is—but a
rubbish heap. Some day, perhaps, Zona Gale's great-granddaughter will ignore the method of realism employed by her revered ancestress, and write a—what?—which actually reproduces
a cross-section of a not-too-mad brain. In it there will be long
lists of object-names, and tail-ends of day-dreams, a charming
hodge-podge with neither rhyme nor reason. In those days, a
novelist may write "he thought," as the sentinel beyond the fence
of quotes, and be at least within the limits of truth.

Dr. 0. G. Harne Addresses
Council on Biologic Background of Behavior
"The Biologic Background of Behavior" was the subject of the address of Dr. 0. G. Harne, Professor
of Pharmacology of the University
of Maryland Medical School, at the
meeting of the Y. M. C. A. Friendship Council, held last Tuesday.
The functions of various glands of
the body in affecting and modifying
the actions were discussed in many
of their various. relationships.
Seven Glands

According to Dr. Harne, the biologic foundation of reaction is encompassed in seven glands located
about the anatomy, of which the
more important are the pituitary
gland, located in the brain, the thyroid, and the adrenal gland, located
somewhat above the kidney. Examples characterized the presentation of this rather difficult and technical discussion of glandular constituency, the most noteworthy being
that of the lowly mouse.
The economic loss of metabolic
processes manifested as a loss of
energy was conveniently typefied by
the example of a weighty pachyderm
traversing perhaps a mile, frightened
by the insignificant mouse jumping
from a ragweed..

Effect of Adrenal Gland

Why does the timid rabbit run
when one throws an object into his
retreat in the shrubbery? And,
conversely, why does a cat remain
fixed under the same class of stimuli? Dr. Harne explained that these
two antithetical operations were
motivated by not an essentially differently constructed mental organism, but by the presence of the adrenal gland. The dual construction of
this very small but immensely important gland consists of a cortex,
or outside, and a medulla, or nucleons. A large cortex is found in
timid animals such as the rabbit, the
medulla being correspondingly small.
In the case of the cat the direct antithesis occurs; namely, the cortex is
small and the medulla large.

11 OPPONENTS FOR
RACQUET WIELDERS
Proctor and Polan Announce
'28 Tennis Schedule—Five
Matches Away
Eleven tennis matches have been
arranged for the 1928 Hopkins tennis team by Manager Bernard Polan
and Captain Kenneth Proctor. Five
of the matches will be played on,
enemy courts, while the remaining
SIX will be.staged at home.
The team will open the season
With a short Southern trip. The
University of Virginia Will be met
April 5, after which the team will
then journey to Lexington, Virginia,
Where the Washington and Lee racqueters will be met the next day.
On April 7, the Jays will complete
their excursion with a match against
Virginia Polytechnic Institute.
•

Cavaliers Return

Franklin and Marshall will be
Played at home on Aprit-20, and
Oil April 26 the Cavaliers from Virginia will visit Homewood to again
match racquets with the Black and
Blue. The Jays will desert Baltimore again on May 1 to play
Georgetown in Washington, but will
return to meet Lafayette on the
fourth.
The annual contest With Maryland
Will be staged at College Park this
Year, and the date will be April 5.
The Terrapins are out to avenge last
Year's defeat, and the Jay racqueters
Will endeavor to help give Hopkins
a clean sweep over their ancient
rivals in all branches of sport during
1927-28.
Last Three Here

• The last three matches of the season will take place at Homewood,
George Washington, New York
University, and Georgetown being
the opponents on May 10, 12 and 15,
respectively.
Proctor is endeavoring to add two
or three more matches to the above
schedule, but no definitE-dates have
been agreed upon as yet.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 10, 1928

ALUMNUS GOSSIP IN "TOWN TOPICS"
Two Hopkins graduates are
the latest victims of Dame Gossip. Town Topics, the scandal sheet of New York, recently published the following statement:
"Chris Johnston has quieted
down quite a bit since his college days, when the Cane Club
was in full swing and he and
Paul Parsons used to go over
to East Baltimore and cut capers. In this way Paul got
in with several of the young
men about town and soon
found himself right in society."
Johnston arid Parsons were
members of the class of 1922,
the former going to the Medical School after his graduation
here. Parsons was a lacrosse
player of note.

Next Jay Will Be
"Wanderlust Number"
According to Donald White, editor-in-chief of the Black and Blue
Jay, the next issue of the Jay will
take its readers to foreign ports
again. "Wanderlust" is the novel
sobriquet given by the Hopkins humorists to this number, which will
appear during the last week in February.
The "Wanderlust Number," stated
White, will be more or less of a
travel number, but treated differently from the so-called "Travel
Numbers" issued in the past. Editorial copy is to be in by the last
of. next week, thus insuring time
enough to get the Jay out by March
1.
The next election of candidates
for the art, editorial and business
staffs will be held immediately after
the Easter recess. Editorial candidates must have their minimum requirement of copy in on time, stated
White, to be eligible for election to
the staff.

DR. C. K. EDMUNDS IS
RECENTLY HONORED
Former Hopkins Provost. Becomes Head of Pomona College; to Try New Experiment
Dr. Charles K. Edmunds, who
was formerly a provost of the Johns
Hopkins University, has been selected as the new head of Pomona
College, ahremont, California.
Besides being connected with
Hopkins, Dr. Edmunds has had interests with Lignon University for
twenty.years. This latter institution was formerly the Canton Christian College, China. First serving
the Chinese college as a member of
its faculty, then as its president, Dr.
Edmunds finally became the director
of the Board of Trustees.

GRADES FOR FIRST
SEMESTER NOW OUT
• For the first time in several
years, official notices of marks
for the first semester are being
placed in the post office boxes
of the students. Official
grades have been sent in, listed,
copied and reports made out.
This has all been done since
examinations.
The girls in the office have
shown surprising efficiency in
getting out the official grades,
and it is hoped that they have
established a precedent that
will be continued. The grades
as statecl in these reports are
official and final, and are not
subject to change.

The distinguished professor will
head one of a group of small colleges; to which equal facilities will
be open. The objcet of this arrangement is to afford the group
the advantages of both the small
college and the large university.
The group is composed of the
Scripps and Pomona colleges, at
present under the name of Claremont Colleges. Another link is to
be added as soon as possible, according to authorities.
Dr. Goodnow's Comment

Dr. Goodnow, president of Hopkins, in speaking of Dr. Edmunds'
new appointment, stated that he was
sorry to see Hopkins lose him. "He
is an excellent man, and I am sure
he will do well in his new work."
added the president.
Under the guidance of the former
provost, the Canton College made
great progress, and became known
as one of the greatest educational
institutions in China. Lignon University is surrounded by 318 acres
of land and consists of 52 permanent
buildings.
One year ago, Dr. Edmunds, with
Dr. William W. Comfort, president
of Haverford College, and Dean
Watts, of Pennsylvania State College, went to China to assist in reorganizing the university "in view
of the nationalistic aspirations of the
Chinese."
The newly appointed head of the
Western college graduated from
Hopkins in 1897, and was the recipient of both the degree of Bachelor of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy from this university. He is a
Fellow of the American Geographical Society and American Physical
Society.

, George Washington's original idea
to found a national university in the
capital of the nation would be affected under the terms of a bill
which has been advocated in the
Senate by Senator Fess, who was
a noted educator before his election
to that body. He proposes to locate an institution of "higher learning," named the National University of the United States, within the
capital, and which would have at its
disposal for scientific research the
$50,000,000 worth of laboratories
and laboratory equipment which are
at present located in Washington.
Under the Fess plan the institution
would be a "super-university." All
students would have to be graduates
of other universities who hold degrees of Master of Arts or Master
of Science; it would be directed by
a board of trustees appointed by
the President with the advice of an
advisory council representing all the
States.

WHY NOT A TRIP FOR THE BARNSTORMERS?
The recent successful Musical Club trip to the Eastern Shore
opens to Hopkins organizations an entirely new field of enterprise, worthy of further exploitation. That section of the State
has too long been looked upon by Baltimoreans as being too inaccessible. As a matter of fact, it is within close proximity of this
city, the trip being a matter of only a few hours.
As the Barnstormers prepare for their new dramatic season
they would do well to consider the possibility of presenting their
play at seireral Eastern Shore towns during the Easter holidays.
It has long seemed the height of folly for the Barnstormers, after
a long period of rehearsing the manuscript and painting the scenery, to give only two public performances. By. the time the actors
have become accustomed to playing their roles before an audience
the play's brief engagement is over.
Members of the club might object to this suggestion on the
grounds of excessive freight charges for transporting stage properties. Such expenditures could easily be eliminated by borrowing
the necessary furniture from merchants in the towns where the
club performs.
People on the Eastern Shore would gladly welcome such an
enterprise. It is a well-known fact that the traveling dramatic
road shows have long ago dropped small towns from their itineraries. Amusement seekers in such drama-starved districts must,
therefore, live on the scanty diet provided by Adolphe Menjou,
Clara Bow and other motion-picture mimes.
The arrival of a good play, capably acted by the Barnstormers,
would create a considerable stir in such towns and should prove
quite profitable at the box office.

DR. GILMAN'S OLD PLEA
There is no more striking note in the publications of the writers
on higher education in this country than that of inadequacy. Despite differences of opinions as pp how the problem is to be met,
the spirit that there is something definitely lacking is, nevertheless,
unanimous.
Typical of articles of this type is one by R. L. Duffus, entitled
"A View of the College of Tomorrow," which appeared in last
Sunday's New York Times. Mr. Duffus believes that one of the
chief weaknesses in American colleges today is the poor quality
of most of the faculties, caused by the insufficiency of endowments. He stresses the point that, except in the extremely rare
case of the man who is willing to join the teaching profession
through pure love of his work, the best scholars and most inspiring
teachers are often lost, because these men are not willing to raise
families on the average salary that most colleges can pay. Nor
does he believe that money alone will be the solution. "Dull instructors beget dull instructors, pedagogically speaking," he says.
There is a great deal to be said in favor of this argument. Inspiring teachers—although not necessarily brilliant scholars—can
often outweigh the evil effects of an inadequate or antiquated system. Although it seems to be becoming more and more patent
every day that the American college must undergo changes in order
to fulfill its mission, it should also be recognized that no matter
how many modifications are made in curricula, these changes
should be accompanied by the attraction to the colleges of men
who cannot only teach youth, but inspire him.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

An alumnus of the University of
Chicago and the president of a large
national concern in that city stated
in a recent address that a college
education is worth $72,000. He
furthermore said that this represents a profit of'1,200 per cent. on
an original investment of $6,000,
which is the average total cost of a
four-year course in college. Deducting the cost of the education
itself, the student adds to his future
income at the rate of $15,000 a year
during the time he is in college. As
classes are held only five days a
week, this means potential earnings
of $70.00 a day to the student for
each day spent in the classroom. We
don't say we believe it all, but doesn't
it work out beautifully on paper?
*

*

*

*

*•

According to information received
from the University of Minnesota,
there is reason to believe that one
student out of every four cheats
in examinations. About 400 students were questioned with the understanding that any information
received would in no way affect their
grades, and that their replies were
to be anonymous. It was then found
that about 18 per cent. of that number were guilty of the offense and
the opinion is that when final investigations are completed the percentage
will have increased to 25.

The following code was recently
published in the undergraduate
newspaper at Syracuse University
as.embodying suggestions from students, faculty and alumni as a basis
for community understanding:
As a Student

I believe that I am entitled
to a full return for time spent
in the classroom and that I

should attempt to secuie it by
a co-operative attitude toward
instructors, a freedom from
antagonism, and evidence of
my desire to understand their
points of view.
I believe that prevalence of
"cribbing" would not only destroy the morals of the college,
but lessen the value of its academic degree. I personally
shall not be guilty of it.
I believe that I have a share
of responsibility for the o'rderly life of the campus, and that
where any form of lawlessness
exists it is my duty to aid in
stamping it out.
I believe that I should not
profit financially by any position of trust or responsibility
connected with student affairs,
unless by an open arrangement fully understood and approved by my fellow students.
I believe that students
should share in the planning
of all legislation which governs student affairs.
As a Teacher

I believe that I should attend
classroom fully prepared, avoiding the stereotyped
lecture and the meaningless
phrase.
I will assume every question,
to be sincerely meant unless I
know to the contrary, and I
will not meet it with sarcasm
or wit at the expense of the
inquirer.
I will avoid pose.
I assert my liberty as a citizen to express freely my opinion on any controversial topic;
but as a representative of the
University I will distinguish
liberty from license, and consider the dignity of the platform upon which I stand.
In publishing my private
opinions I will see to it that
they are represented as my
own and not those of the body
of which I now happen to be
a part.
I believe that the classroom
must not be used for purposes
of propaganda. I consider it
my task to encourage students
to seek the truth, not to force
them to accept my interpretation of it.
I believe that my right to
devote a classroom hour to subject matter remote from the
business of the course is coextendent with the right of the
student to use that hour for
purposes equally remote.
I believe that instructors and
students are assembled here
primarily to carry out an educational program and that any
subordinate interest which
comes into conflict with that

does the examination take its place.
The ideal combination consists of
Short tests, two examinations every
Year with long questions, and the
term paper. If I don't give tests
they will not do the work. We must
also remember that in the world we
are always checked up in one way
or another."
Dr. French Sympathetic

Dr. John C. French, on the other
hand, expresses himself as, in general, favorable to the proposed plan
of dropping examinations in English Literature. Dr. John Earle
Uhler is sick and could not be interviewed. Instructors in the English
ilepartment refused to comment.

Satyr's Lament
That day there 'blew a breeze
Which winnowed winsomely, and brought
A tremor to the lush grass, rippling
Whisp'ringly the tender green,
And shimmering in the trees.
I may be hard to please,
For one who seeks the thing I sought;
God knows—the glistening golden sheen
Of sunlight on the ruffed pool,
And blown leaf-shadows, stippling
Your glowing body, and the breeze—
But stay—
The day was young—and sweet—and wild
And you were such a—fragile—child. .

Pick-Up?
Underfoot the cold rain made sloppy holes in the lingering
custard of snow. The green and 'red lights of traffic posts ran
down the shining black street in alternate 'streams of blood and
absinthe. And toward me came—she. What. I thought, as the
instant recognition of that slightly swaying slimness flashed her
identity through my brain, is she doing on this street, which is so
foreign to her meaning, so distinctly not her street, at this hour of
an adventurous but highly aristocratic evening? 'She saw me;
knew me instantly for the strange, ftinny self-conscious boy who
looked—so often—and smiled—so . . . Because it was an adventurous if aristocratic evening, I slackened my somewhat uncertain
steps. Rebellion burned in her clear eyes, and in her eyes was the
glowing danger of the traffic sign. I looked and smiled.
She placed her feet firmly in the slush. "Why," said she, "are
you always looking at me—and smiling?" Her voice, at last.
Such a voice as it should be—melody under coarse fur—or some
such absurdly impossible thing.
Carefully I paused. "That," I answered, -is too easy. You
are pleasing to look at; T smile when I'm pleased. Where are you
going
"Home, I guess . . . What's it to you. anyway?"
"I'll walk to the bus with you."
"I take the street car."
"Not generally."
"You must be cheap, ain't you?"
"Why?"
The answer was a look. It was no answer. Amusement, a
slight boredom, a dare, a request . . . who can say? A nauseous yellow taxi slithered to a halt in red obedience. A white leer
like something long drowned marred its misted windowpane.
There was a drunken yell.
"Gen'rally," she spat at me quietly, "I take a taxi." She took
the taxi. .
. Perhaps it was a friend of hers. .

No trifle hurtled carlessly,

knew that words and petty faults could sting-Desired the pain that love would bring ;

"The world is so full of a number of matters,
I'm sure we should all be as crazy as hatters."
How can anyone pretend to thought, when thought is a mere
mad whirl of images and urtmentionable, idiotic dreamings, when
the expression of a thought so frequently precedes realization of
a mental process? To argue or to write is to find out what you
think; in either caw the discovery is astounding-, and one stands
amazed, like
"Stout Cortez . . .
Silent on a peak in Darien."
Bu think what you really think; the disconnected fragments of
totally irrelevant and unrelated reveries that chase each other
through your brain. My mind to me—not a kingdom is—but a
rubbish heap. Some day, perhaps, Zona Gale's great-granddaughter will ignore the method of realism employed by her revered ancestress, and write a—what?—which actually reproduces
a cross-section of a not-too-mad brain. In it there will be long
lists of object-names, and tail-ends of day-dreams, a charming
hodge-podge with neither rhyme nor reason. In those days, a
novelist may write "he thought," as the sentinel beyond the fence
of quotes, and be at least within the limits of truth.

Dr. 0. G. Harne Addresses
Council on Biologic Background of Behavior
"The Biologic Background of Behavior" was the subject of the address of Dr. 0. G. Harne, Professor
of Pharmacology of the University
of Maryland Medical School, at the
meeting of the Y. M. C. A. Friendship Council, held last Tuesday.
The functions of various glands of
the body in affecting and modifying
the actions were discussed in many
of their various. relationships.
Seven Glands

According to Dr. Harne, the biologic foundation of reaction is encompassed in seven glands located
about the anatomy, of which the
more important are the pituitary
gland, located in the brain, the thyroid, and the adrenal gland, located
somewhat above the kidney. Examples characterized the presentation of this rather difficult and technical discussion of glandular constituency, the most noteworthy being
that of the lowly mouse.
The economic loss of metabolic
processes manifested as a loss of
energy was conveniently typefied by
the example of a weighty pachyderm
traversing perhaps a mile, frightened
by the insignificant mouse jumping
from a ragweed..

Effect of Adrenal Gland

Why does the timid rabbit run
when one throws an object into his
retreat in the shrubbery? And,
conversely, why does a cat remain
fixed under the same class of stimuli? Dr. Harne explained that these
two antithetical operations were
motivated by not an essentially differently constructed mental organism, but by the presence of the adrenal gland. The dual construction of
this very small but immensely important gland consists of a cortex,
or outside, and a medulla, or nucleons. A large cortex is found in
timid animals such as the rabbit, the
medulla being correspondingly small.
In the case of the cat the direct antithesis occurs; namely, the cortex is
small and the medulla large.
